01.text: Jesus tells a parable about a landowner who hires workers, to illustrate how God will reward those who belong to the kingdom of heaven.

01.ref: For the kingdom of heaven is like
01.text: This is the beginning of a parable. See how you translated the introduction to the parable in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:13:24|13:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

01.ref: he sent them into his vineyard
01.text: "he sent them to work in his vineyard"

03.text: The third hour is around nine in the morning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"standing in the marketplace not doing anything" or "standing in the marketplace with no work to do"
a large, open-air area where people buy and sell food and other items

05.ref: the sixth hour and again the ninth hour
05.text: The sixth hour is around noon. The ninth hour is around three in the afternoon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
This means the landowner went to the marketplace and hired workers.
This is about five in the afternoon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
"not doing anything" or "not having any work"

08.ref: beginning from the last to the first
08.text: You can make clear the understood information. AT: "begin with the workers I hired last, then pay the workers I hired first" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom the landowner hired" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

11.text: "When the workers who had worked the longest received"

11.ref: you have made them equal to us
11.text: "you have paid them the same amount of money as you paid us"

11.ref: we who have borne the burden of the day and the scorching heat
11.text: The phrase "borne the burden of the day" is an idiom that means they worked very hard. AT: "we who have worked hard all day in the heat of the sun" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

13.text: "one of the workers who had worked the longest"
Use a word that one man would use to address another man whom he is politely rebuking.

13.ref: Did you not agree with me for one denarius?
13.text: The landowner uses a question to rebuke the workers who were complaining. AT: "We already agreed that I would give you one denarius" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

15.text: Jesus concludes his parable about a landowner who hires workers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_parables]])

15.ref: Do I not have the right to do as I want with what belongs to me?
15.text: The landowner uses a question to scold the workers who were complaining.  AT: "I can do what I want with my own possessions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

15.ref: Or are you envious because I am generous?
15.text: The landowner uses a question to scold the workers who were complaining. AT: "Do not be jealous because I am generous to other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

15.ref: So the last will be first, and the first last
15.text: Jesus is comparing this age to the next age. Those who are important now, God will consider them unimportant when he establishes his rule on earth. Those who seem unimportant now, God will consider them important when he establishes his rule. See how you translated a similar statement in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:19:29|19:30]].

15.ref: So the last will be first
15.text: Here the parable has ended and Jesus is speaking. AT: "Then Jesus said, 'So the last will be first'"

17.text: Jesus foretells his death and resurrection a third time as he and his disciples travel to Jerusalem.
Jerusalem was on top of a hill so people had to travel up to get there.
Jesus uses the word "See" to tell the disciples the must pay attention to what he is about to tell them.
Here "we" refers to Jesus and the disciples. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

17.ref: the Son of Man will be delivered
17.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone will deliver the Son of Man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Jesus is referring to himself in the third person. If necessary, you can translate these in the first person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

17.ref: They will condemn ... for them to mock
17.text: The chief priests and scribes will condemn and deliver him to the Gentiles, and the Gentiles will mock Jesus.
"to whip him" or "to beat him with whips"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will raise him up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

20.text: In response to the question that the mother of two of the disciples asks, Jesus teaches his disciples about authority and serving others in the kingdom of heaven.

20.ref: at your right hand ... at your left hand
20.text: These refer to having positions of power, authority, and honor. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "kingdom" refers to Jesus ruling as king. AT: "when you are king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

22.text: Here "you" is plural and refers to the mother and the sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "you" is plural, but Jesus is only talking to the two sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

22.ref: drink the cup that I am about to drink
22.text: This is an idiom that means to experience suffering. AT: "go through the suffering I am about to go through" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"The sons of Zebedee said" or "James and John said"

22.ref: My cup you will indeed drink
22.text: This is an idiom that means to experience suffering. AT: "You will indeed suffer as I will suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
These refer to having positions of power, authority, and honor. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:20:20|20:21]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

22.ref: it is for those for whom it has been prepared by my Father
22.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "my Father has prepared those places, and he will give them to whom he chooses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an important title for God that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"heard what James and John had asked Jesus"

22.ref: they were very angry with the two brothers
22.text: If necessary, you can make explicit why the ten disciples were angry. AT: "they were very angry with the two brothers because each of them wanted to sit in the places of honor next to Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

25.text: Jesus finishes teaching his disciples about authority and serving others.

25.ref: the rulers of the Gentiles subjugate them
25.text: "the Gentile kings forcefully rule over their people"

25.ref: the Son of Man ... his life
25.text: Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. If necessary, you can translate this in the first person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

25.ref: did not come to be served
25.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "did not come so that other people would serve him" or "did not come so that other people would serve me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
You can make clear the understood information. AT: "but to serve other people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This is an idiom. AT: "to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The word "ransom" usually refers to setting someone free from prison or slavery. Here it is a metaphor for Jesus saving people from God punishing them for their sins. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
You can make clear the understood information. AT: "for many people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

29.text: This begins an account of Jesus healing two blind men.
This refers to the disciples and Jesus.

29.ref: There were two blind men were sitting
29.text: This is sometimes translated as "Behold, there were two men sitting." The writer is alerting us to a new people in the story. Your language may have a way of doing this.

Jesus was not David's literal son, so this may be translated as "Descendant of King David" (UDB). However, "Son of David" is also a title for the Messiah, and the men were probably calling Jesus by this title.

32.ref: that our eyes may be opened
32.text: The phrase "our eyes may be opened" is an idiom that means to be able to see again. This can be stated in active form. AT: "we want you to make us able to see" or "we want to be able to see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
